recto.line: ñā na w[i] ///
jñ· na wi r[y]e
[śi] lo pa ke
·e ·e
[o] [k]au¯ ¯R a lā se śau mo ke ta tse pe rpe te : mā su mlu tke TA[¯] [¯R] meṃ ke ta ra : ke tra [ś]· ykai [p]e [l]e sa kre[¯] : pau su swkä [n]meṃ kre tau na meṃ pRA¯ ¯K ke ta¯ ¯R |

pada.s:
okaur (?) an inert person whose burden is heavy [lit. thick] - he does not escape from ... of anyone.
okaur alāse śaumo ket= atse perpete :

s.tr: Whose ... through the good law, he ... from bliss and virtues ....
s.s: ket ra ś· ykai pelesa kre(nt) :

pada.s: pau su swkänmeṃ kretaunameṃ präk ketar |

comments.comment: 14+11+11+11 syllables

Zhao and Rong read ket= ats[e] ·ṣu perpette, Pinault reads ket= atseṣ[ṣ]e perpette. The first seems to be closer to the truth: There appears to be a u-diacritic present. The main body of the akṣara is obscured by damage on the wall.

The akṣara is not legible. Zhao and Rong read kre[n]ta[n], explaining it as a mistake for krentäṃ. I follow Pinault here. However, maybe we could read pele sakre[nts] "the law/manner of the blissful" - to my eyes, the akṣara looks most like ntS.

There are three hapax legomena here: pau, präk, ketar. Zhao and Rong read präkketär, which they explain as a late form of präṅketär. However, the präk is written with virāma, making this rather unlikely. I would conjecture that ketar is some sort of late shortened form of ketara. This would make the two clauses in this inscription parallel in form.

recto.line: ste re jñā
caṃ ndre st[e] re ā
[ryo] t[t]ā me ce

transcription.prose:
stere jñā(na)
caṃndre stere ā
ryo ttāme ce…

prose.s: Not for long did he teach the law well. mā wa(l)k(e) ṅk(e) epikte kart(s)e āk(ṣ)a pel(ai)kne

In these stūpas, if there are two... completely... bit by bit now this later... never ... näk· r : t(o)yak ptanmasa krāma tau wi tākaṃ snai lyīpär
yke-postäṃ : s· k ñke te post(aññ)e ma(nta)k lī ·e m·nai
They get drink from another home. cey alyek o(sta)meṃ yoksi kälwāskem pelai

comments.comment: The transcription is a compromise between Pinault and Zhao and Rong. The plaster on top of which the inscription is written has broken off in a lot of places. This makes the inscription exceedingly difficult to read.

recto.line: sa lpeṃ pi¯ ¯Ś cme la a ñi tyā tṣe pu wa [r]sa • ko¯ ¯y[N]ä ka kā ya ṣp[o] [k]a ṣā nta [ṣṣ]i kā ri po • tā ṣṭä¯ ¯R pe lai kne śau la nma sa KA ryau se • [tn]e ka pre ksau me kā snai meṃ «ts[i]» KLA[ṃ] tsa ñce¯ ¯R

strophe.pada: koyn kakāyaṣ po ; kaṣāntaṣṣi , kāri po •
Les cinq naissances brûlent dans le feu de l'impermanence.
Tous ayant ouvert la bouche [sont] tous des fosses d'ordures.
La loi est établie, elle qui [a été] achetée par les vies.
Ici donc je vous demande : Pourquoi dormez-vous sans souci?
Those of the five-births burn in the fire of inconstancy,
all having opened their mouths, all are pits of kapānta,
he establishes the law and bought [it] with lives,
here indeed I ask you, "how do you sleep without a care?"

comments.comment: metre 4x12, rythm 5/7

recto.line: ra vai ññe meṃ nne śa¯ ¯Kä vi ne a mp[R]ä ta śa rme • mo k[ṣ]a gu pte • dha rma kā me ta ne spe lke ya ma ṣṣa re a bhi dhā¯ ¯RMä tu ntse te ṣo tri dha rma kā me pai yka :

line.tr: Dans la sixième année de règne du roi Kṣemārjuna, dans l'année du Cheval, dans le dixième mois, le premier jour, trois jeunes novices – Puṇyacandra, Jñānacandra, Amṛtarakṣita – sont venus ici ; de cela
Jñānacandra a écrit le signe.

transcription.prose:
(pa)ñ(ä)ktäññe yātka-c ||
|| nano śikhiṃ pañäk(t)e śwātsi kakātai saṅkrām yamaṣa(t)ai walo ṣait ||
walo (ṣ)ai(t) śikhiṃ(nt)s(e) pkai kṣ(āt)re(ṃnt)s(a) y(a)rke yām(aṣa)st(a) saṅkrām yamaṣa(sta)
|| nano walo ṣait śikhiṃ wrantsai lac pkai kṣātreṃntsa yarke yamaṣasta-ne śaultsa warñai riś kakātai-ne
|| nano alyekepi śikhiṃntse pkai kṣātreṃntsa yarke yāmormeṃ rīne stämäṣṣatai-ne
|| tane śikhiṃ pañäktentse śarka ploriyaisa yarke yamaṣasta walo ṣait
|| nano śikhiṃ ra kakātai sāṅkäṣṣ(e) pelaikne kly(au)ṣtsi rano yarke yāmṣasta
|| nano walo ṣait śikhiṃ g(ā)kne nāskäṣṣatai (vyā)karit yama ///

line.tr: ... the Buddha-like commanded you.
Again you invited Buddha Śikhin for eating; you made a monastery; you were a king.
Tu étais roi; (après avoir rendu hommage à Śikhin avec parasol [et] chasse-mouches), pour la durée de la vie tu établis un monastère.

Derechef, tu étais roi; tu sortis à la rencontre de Śikhin; avec parasol [et] chasse-mouches tu lui rendis hommage; (pour le temps) tout au long de la vie (= pour toute la vie) tu l'invitas à la ville.
Derechef, après avoir rendu hommage à un autre Śikhin avec parasol [et] chasse-mouches, dans la ville tu l'installas.
Ici, au Buddha Śikhin tu rendis hommage avec (de la musique de) flûte [et] luth; tu etais roi.
Derechef, tu invitas aussi Śikhin; désireux d'observer la loi de la Communauté, tu rendis hommage.
Derechef tu étais roi; Śikhin se laissa baigner (?) dans le Gange (...).

comments.comment: Drawings in ; photos in , pl. 163, 164.
read śwātsi against ([ṣaul]tsa).
read and restore [yā]m(aṣa)st(a) against ((yā)m(ormeṃ) [ś](au)[ltsa]).
read and restore against ([pāṣ]ts(i) r[i]tau).

internalComments.comment: Why dīpamālṣa? From what I can recognize from the (poor quality) photograph in Zhao and Rong's edition, there seem to be a Fremdzeichen L.

recto.line: || tu meṃ w[ā] s[a] vi lā nte tkā ce¯ ¯R ra tna śi khiṃ dī pa mā lṣa e ka ññe wa sa ||
pra ṇā deṃ ri śka kā tai ñu mka pta nma tsai ka tai ||
ṣe ma ṅka rsa kwa rSA¯ ¯R o ro cce pa¯ ¯T laṃ ṣā tai ||
brā hma ṇe śrī sa mbha veṃ l[y]ā [ka] ytā ri sa wṣe ñai wsā ne ||
rṣā k[e] ṣai¯ ¯T k[au] ṇḍi nye ntse w· pai ne wṣe ñai wsā sta o ko nta ṢPA ||
di pa ṅka rsa ṣu ktu ppā lnta ṣa lā sta brā hmaṃ ñe kā lśke ṣai¯ ¯T ||
rṣā ke ṣai¯ ¯T su da rśa neṃ pa ñä kte wra ntsai la¯ ¯cä ||
na no rṣā ke ṣai¯ ¯T su ne tri wa rto ne ya rk[e] y[ā] mṣa sta ||
ṣṭ· [dh]ṛ [ti] rā ṣṭre ntse kuṣā tre [y]· [r]·e ///

prose.s:
Thereupon the daughter of king Vāsava gave Ratnaśikhin the equipement for a lamp garland.
|| tumeṃ wāsavi lānte tkācer ratnaśikhiṃ dīpamālṣa ekaññe wasa ||

You invited Praṇāda to the city;
praṇādeṃ riś kakātai
you built ninety stūpas. ñumka ptanma tsaikatai ||

During [the age of] Kṣemaṅkara, you established a one-league large stūpa.
ṣemaṅkarsa kwarsär orocce pat laṃṣātai ||

A Brahmin saw Śrīsambhava;
brāhmaṇe śrīsambhaveṃ lyāka
on the way he gave him a resting place. ytārisa wṣeñai wsā-ne ||

You were a Rṣi;
rṣāke ṣait
to Kauṇḍinya you gave a footstool and fruits. kauṇḍinyentse w(i)-paine-wṣeñai wsāsta okonta ṣpä ||

On Dipaṅkara you threw seven lotus [flowers];
dipaṅkarsa ṣukt uppālnta ṣalāsta
you were a Brahmin boy [then]. brāhmaṃñe kālśke ṣait ||

You were a Rṣi;
rṣāke ṣait
you went out towards the Buddha Sudarśana. sudarśaneṃ pañäkte wrantsai lac ||

Again you were a Rṣi;
nano rṣāke ṣait
to Sunetra you did homage in the forest. sunetri wartone yarke yāmṣasta ||
... (with) a parasol (you did) homage to Dhṛtarāṣṭra ... ṣṭ· dhṛtirāṣṭrentse kUṣātre(sa) y(a)r(k)e ///

comments.comment: The reading is based on , the translation on .
Drawings in ; photos in , pl. 163, 164.
Note dīpamālṣa (thus read by with fn. 1 contra with fn. 2, p. 176), which stands either for masculine dīpamālṣe or for fem. dīpamālṣai.
Note that read l[y]ā[ka] 'he saw' instead of [katko]ṣ\, as per .
Note that read okonta 'fruits' instead of okronta, as per and 182.

transcription.prose:
(kak)ātai (pa)t s(a)ṅ(k)rām yama(ṣa)sta-ne ||
n(a)no (tw)e (pra)senaji walo pañäkte p··aṃ ne ṣṣe saṅk(r)ām

line.tr: You invited (Buddha xy); you made a stūpa [and] a monastery.
Again you [were] king Prasenajit; the Buddha ... the monastery of ...
